facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 164 and 165 of 1972 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 164 and 165 of. 1972. Petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights. K. Sen,  in W.P. No. 164  B. Sen,  in W.P. No. 165  Krishna Sen, S. R. Agarwala and R. K. Khanna, for the petitioners.

facts.text: Ramanlal Bhogilal Shah was General Manager of United Commercial Bank Ltd. till January 17, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, Ramanlal Bhogilal Shah, was the Gene- ral Manager of United Commercial Bank Ltd. till January 17, 1968 when he became the Chairman and whole time Director of the said bank.

facts.text: Ramanlal Bhogilal Shah became Chairman and whole time Director of United Commercial Bank Ltd. on January 17, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: till January 17, 1968 when he became the Chairman and whole time Director of the said bank. Upon nationalisation of the bank, the petitioner was appointed Custodian thereof and he companytinued as Custodian till September 1, 1971.

facts.text: Upon nationalisation, Ramanlal Bhogilal Shah appointed Custodian of United Commercial Bank till September 1, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: the said bank. Upon nationalisation of the bank, the petitioner was appointed Custodian thereof and he companytinued as Custodian till September 1, 1971. On June 4, 1966 the United Commercial Bank had booked a forward exchange companytract for Hindustan Motors for pound 9,32,617 at the rate of 1s. 529/32d, per rupee.

facts.text: United Commercial Bank booked forward exchange contract for Hindustan Motors on June 4, 1966 for Â£9,32,617 at rate 1s. 529/32d per rupee.

anchor.surface_text: On June 4, 1966 the United Commercial Bank had booked a forward exchange companytract for Hindustan Motors for pound 9,32,617 at the rate of 1s. 529/32d, per rupee. On June 6, 1966, the rupee was devalued.

facts.text: Rupee was devalued on June 6, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: per rupee. On June 6, 1966, the rupee was devalued. K. Guha, Deputy Director, Enforcement Directorate, was making into certain offences under the Exchange Act.

facts.text: Petitioner served summons under S.19F of FERA 1947 on May 24, 1971 by Shri D.K. Guha, Deputy Director, Enforcement Directorate.

K. Guha, Deputy Director, Enforcement Directorate, was making into certain offences under the Exchange Act.

facts.text: Petitioner examined under summons on June 3, 1971, June 16, 1971 and June 17, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was examined on June 3, 1971, June 16, 1971 and June 17, 1971. According to the petitioner, the entire examination on the said dates related to the booking by the United Commercial Bank of the aforesaid forward exchange companytract dated June 4, 1966.

facts.text: Examinations related to forward exchange contract of June 4, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: According to the petitioner, the entire examination on the said dates related to the booking by the United Commercial Bank of the aforesaid forward exchange companytract dated June 4, 1966. On August 31, 1971, the petitioner was arrested unders. 19B of the Exchange Act.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested under S.19B of FERA on August 31, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: On August 31, 1971, the petitioner was arrested unders. 19B of the Exchange Act. Sub-section  1  of S. 19B provides that if any officer of Enforcement . . . has reason to believe that any person in India or within the Indian customs waters has been guilty of an offence punishable under the Exchange Act, he may arrest such person and shall, as soon as may be, inform him of the grounds for such arrest.

facts.text: Grounds of arrest served on petitioner detailing reasons for belief of offences under S.42 and S.22 FERA punishable under S.23.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds of arrest served on the petitioner are elaborate. These give detailed reasons why the enforcement officer had reasons to believe that the petitioner had been guilty of an offence under s. 4 2  and under S. 22 of the Exchange Act punishable under s. 23 thereof.

facts.text: Petitioner produced before Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta on August 31, 1971 and released on bail of Rs.10,000 with conditions.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was produced before the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta, on August 31, 1971, who released him on bail of Rs. 10,000 with the direction that the petitioner should companytact the Investigating Officer every alternate day during the next two weeks and thereafter as and when called for.

facts.text: Chief Presidency Magistrate order on September 6, 1971: allowed three months time for report till December 6, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: On September 6, 1971, the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta, recorded Both accused are on C.B. and present. Perused report submitted by I.O. I.O. prays for three months time for submitting further report. Time allowed till 6-12-71 for submission of report.

facts.text: Chief Presidency Magistrate order on December 6, 1971: further three months time till March 6, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: On December 6, 1971, the order is recorded as follows Both accused are on C.B. and present. Perused report submitted by Enforcement Directorate. Further three months time. Time allowed till 6-3-72 for companypletion of investigation.

facts.text: Chief Presidency Magistrate order on March 6, 1972: time allowed till June 1972 for report.

This First Information Report deals with the forward exchange companytract purported to have been entered on June 4, 1966 by M S Hindusthan Motors Ltd. and the United Commercial Bank Ltd.

facts.text: FIR alleges offences under S.120B r/w 420 IPC and S.2 r/w 23(1)(b) FERA against management and officers of UCB and Hindustan Motors regarding June 4, 1966 contract.

anchor.surface_text: This First Information Report deals with the forward exchange companytract purported to have been entered on June 4, 1966 by M S Hindusthan Motors Ltd. and the United Commercial Bank Ltd. The offences alleged in the first Information Report are s. 120B read with s. 420 I.P.C., and under s.  2  read with s. 23 1   b  of the Exchange Act, and the names and addresses of the accused are given as the Management and other officers of the United Commercial Bank and the Management and officers of the Hindusthan Motors Ltd.

facts.text: Summons issued to petitioner under S.19F FERA on April 17, 1972 to appear on April 28, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: On April 17, 1972 another summons was issued, to the peti- tioner under s. 19-F of the Exchange Act to appear before, the Deputy Director, Enforcement Directorate, on April 28, 1972 to give evidence relating to the transaction of exchange companytract booked from Hindusthan Motors Ltd. on June 4,1966.

facts.text: Petitioner filed present writ petition on April 27, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner thereupon filed the present petition on April,27, 1972.

facts.text: Court held petitioner is a person accused of an offence within Art.20(3) due to FIR.

anchor.surface_text: Although we held that the petitioner is a person accused of an offence within the meaning of art. 20 3 , the only protection that art. 20 3  gives to him is that he cannot be companypelled to be a witness against himself.

precedents.citation: Romesh Chandra, Mehta v. State of West Bengal. 1

anchor.surface_text: Romesh Chandra, Mehta v. State of West Bengal. 1 He strongly relies on the following passage at p. 479 It was strenuously urged that under s. 104 of the Customs Act, 1962, the Customs Officer may arrest a person only if he has reason to believe that any person in India or within the Indian Customs waters has been guilty of an offence punishable under S. 135 and not otherwise and he is bound to inform such person of the grounds of his arrest. Arrest of the person who is guilty of the offence punishable under s. 135 and information to be given to him amount, it was contended, to a formal accusation of an offence and in any case the person who has been arrested and who have been informed of the nature of the infraction committed by him stands in the character of an accused person.

precedents.case_name: Romesh Chandra Mehta v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Arrest under provision similar to s.19B and informing grounds does not amount to formal accusation of an offence; person not accused until complaint filed
precedents.cited_holding: by informing such person of the grounds of his arrest the Customs Officer does not formally accuse him with the commission of an offence. Arrest and detention are only for the purpose of holding effectively an inquiry... until a complaint is so filed the person... does not stand in the character of a person accused of an offence under s. 135.

anchor.surface_text: Romesh Mehtas case 1 no enquiry had been made while in the present case an enquiry under s. 19F had been made and the Deputy Director had come to a definite conclusion that the petitioner was guilty of an offence. He further says that the next step would be an enquiry under s. 23 of the Exchange Act which might result in a penalty under s. 23 (1) (a) or the case being sent to a Court for trial.

precedents.case_name: Romesh Chandra Mehta v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: In the cited case no enquiry under s.19F had been made unlike present case

precedents.citation: M. P. Sharma v. Satish Chandra 2

anchor.surface_text: In M. P. Sharma v. Satish Chandra 2 where search warrants were issued against persons who had been included in the category of accused in the first information report, Jagannadhadas, J., observed at p. 1088 Nor is there any reason to think that the Protection in respect of the evidence so procured is confined to what transpires at the trial in the court room. The phrase used in article 20 (3) is to be a witness and not to appear as a witness-. It follows that the protection afforded to an accused in so far as it is related to the phrase to be a witness is not merely in respect of testimonial compulsion in the court room but may well extend to compelled testimony previously obtained from him. It is available therefore to a person against whom a formal accusation relating to the commission of an offence has been levelled which in the normal course may result in prosecution.

precedents.case_name: M. P. Sharma v. Satish Chandra
precedents.cited_proposition: Lodging of first information report amounts to formal accusation making person accused within art. 20(3); protection extends to compelled testimony before trial
precedents.cited_holding: It is available therefore to a person against whom a formal accusation relating to the commission of an offence has been levelled which in the normal course may result in prosecution.

precedents.citation: Raja Narayanlal Bansilal v. Maneck Phiroz Mistry 1

anchor.surface_text: In Raja Narayanlal Bansilal v. Maneck Phiroz Mistry 1 it was observed Similarly, for invoking the constitutional right against testimonial compulsion guaranteed under Art 20 (3) it must appear that a formal accusation has been made against the party pleading the guarantee and that it relates to the commission of an offence which in the normal course may result in prosecution.

precedents.case_name: Raja Narayanlal Bansilal v. Maneck Phiroz Mistry
precedents.cited_proposition: For art.20(3), formal accusation must have been made relating to commission of offence likely to result in prosecution
precedents.cited_holding: Similarly, for invoking the constitutional right against testimonial compulsion guaranteed under Art 20 (3) it must appear that a formal accusation has been made against the party pleading the guarantee and that it relates to the commission of an offence which in the normal course may result in prosecution.

precedents.citation: Romesh Chand Mehta v. State of West Bengal 2

anchor.surface_text: In Romesh Chand Mehta v. State of West Bengal 2 Shah, J., after reviewing a number of authorities, observed at p. 472 Normally a person stands in the character of an ,accused when a First Information Report is lodged against him in respect of an offence before an Officer competent to Investigate it, or when a complaint is made relating to the commission of an offence before a Magistrate competent to try or send to another Magistrate for trial of the offence.

precedents.case_name: Romesh Chandra Mehta v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Person stands accused when FIR lodged against him before competent officer or complaint before magistrate
precedents.cited_holding: Normally a person stands in the character of an accused when a First Information Report is lodged against him in respect of an offence before an Officer competent to Investigate it, or when a complaint is made relating to the commission of an offence before a Magistrate competent to try or send to another Magistrate for trial of the offence.

precedents.citation: State of Bombay V. Kathi Kalu Oghad 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court observed in State of Bombay V. Kathi Kalu Oghad 1 as follows. In order that a testimony by an accused person may be said to have been self- incriminatory the compulsion of which comes within the, prohibition of the constitutional provision, it- must be of such a character that by itself it should have the tendency of incriminating the accused, if not also of actually doing so. In. other words, it should be a statement which makes the case against the accused person alteast probable, considered by itself.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. Kathi Kalu Oghad
precedents.cited_proposition: Testimony is self-incriminatory only if it has tendency to incriminate the accused by making case probable
precedents.cited_holding: In order that a testimony by an accused person may be said to have been self- incriminatory the compulsion of which comes within the, prohibition of the constitutional provision, it- must be of such a character that by itself it should have the tendency of incriminating the accused, if not also of actually doing so. In. other words, it should be a statement which makes the case against the accused person alteast probable, considered by itself.

outcome.relief_summary: Petition allowed to the limited extent of declaring the petitioner to be a person accused of an offence within Article 20(3) of the Constitution; summons not set aside
directions: Petitioner must appear before the Deputy Director and answer such questions as do not tend to incriminate him, as explained by this Court

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Solicitor General says that the petitioner had not been specifically named as accused in the First Information Report and, therefore, he is not entitled to the protection under Art. 20 3 . We are unable to agree with him in this respect.

anchor.surface_text: Although we held that the petitioner is a person accused of an offence within the meaning of art. 20 3 , the only protection that art. 20 3  gives to him is that he cannot be compelled to be a witness against himself.

Although we held that the petitioner is a person accused of an offence within the meaning of art. 20 3 , the only protection that art. 20 3  gives to him is that he cannot be compelled to be a witness against himself.
